title: Antony Price: Fashion's Theatrical Visionary and His Enduring Influence on Music and Royalty
summary: Antony Price, the esteemed British fashion designer, has died at 80, concluding a prolific career spanning over five decades marked by sculptured silhouettes and theatrical aesthetics that revolutionized style for musical and royal figures. Renowned for pastel suits in Duran Duran's Rio video and the jacket in David Bowie's As The World Falls Down, Price's collaborations extended to Roxy Music and Queen Camilla, showcasing his versatility. Born in Keighley, he studied at the Royal College of Art, beginning his professional journey with menswear designs, including the iconic buttoned trousers for Mick Jagger's 1969 Gimme Shelter tour. Founding his label in 1979, he staged influential shows with models like Jerry Hall, and his technical proficiency in blending menswear and womenswear earned him acclaim as a 'true original' from the British Fashion Council. His final collection in London, featuring Lily Allen in a Diana-inspired dress, preceded his death, underscoring his ongoing innovation. Tributes from Duran Duran highlight his visionary creativity and personal warmth, while his work reflects broader cultural shifts in gender norms and performance art, cementing his legacy in fashion history.

background_read: Antony Price emerged as a key figure in late 20th-century fashion, operating at the intersection of art, music, and celebrity culture. His training at the Royal College of Art during the 1960s placed him within a transformative period for British design, where he developed a signature style that challenged conventional gender boundaries through body-hugging silhouettes. Collaborations with glam rock icons like David Bowie and Duran Duran not only defined visual aesthetics in music videos but also contributed to the androgynous trends of the era. His later work with Queen Camilla demonstrates adaptability across different clienteles, reflecting broader societal acceptance of diverse fashion expressions. Analyzing Price's career offers insights into the evolution of fashion as a cultural force, highlighting how designers mediate between personal creativity and public persona, and the lasting impact of theatricality in contemporary style.
Article_Structure: Main Points: Antony Price's death at 80 marks the end of a career defined by sculptured, theatrical designs that influenced music legends and royalty, with key works including pastel suits for Duran Duran and collaborations with David Bowie. Purpose: To memorialize his life and assess his legacy, situating his work within cultural shifts in fashion and performance.
